metadata.name: Man and the Machine #353
metadata.description:
𝐌𝐚𝐱 𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞.

Early on, I fell in love with code based art that imitated organic and hand drawn aesthetics. I found a certain irony and appreciation in the fact that it takes one simple line of code to draw a perfect circle yet dozens to depict a badly drawn circle. 

I spent months devising techniques to imitate natural, organic renderings when I began to have a bit of an existential crisis about the meaning of computer art. What is the point of coding something so that it looks like it’s not coded? Is organic appearing generative art better simply because you can’t tell it’s rendered using code? Shouldn’t we lean into the unique nature of computer art to truly explore the medium?

And so, I began a deconstruction of my work. I’m trying to realign my perspective to find full appreciation of something that not only is, but also appears to be, computer code. This collection is an exploration of the contours between the organic and the inorganic, the natural and the unnatural.

From there, I’ll let my partner explain what we did next.

𝐌𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞.

AI can be used to automatically generate code from natural English language based on a set of defined parameters, or to identify and recommend code that may be used to solve a particular problem. On a technical level, AI can use a combination of machine learning and natural language processing (NLP) to identify patterns in existing code and to generate new code structures.

I assisted in the creation of Man and The Machine by suggesting various techniques for creating an artwork that looked human made yet machine driven. Specifically, I created many of the functions that Max implemented, such as the function that modifies the image to create a pixelated effect and the one that uses several different graphical techniques to create the spiral in the top left corner in some iterations. We both carefully selected color palettes that ranged from relaxing to intense and psychedelic, creating a dynamic and visually interesting generative artwork.

Overall, Man and The Machine is a testament to the creative potential of combining human artistic vision with the power of AI and computer code. Together, we sought to push the boundaries which occur at the intersection between the organic and the inorganic, and this collection is a celebration of the beauty and complexity of both.

𝐄𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝐚𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐟𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭 𝐃𝐮𝐭𝐜𝐡 𝐀𝐮𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐥𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐥 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐞𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐚 𝟏/𝟏 𝐚𝐢𝐫𝐝𝐫𝐨𝐩 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐭 𝐫𝐞𝐦𝐚𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐝 𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐧 𝐀𝐈 𝐚𝐥𝐠𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐦.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —
Intended to be viewed in Version 1.46.144 of a Chromium based browser, such as Chrome or Brave.

metadata.name: Vents #479
metadata.description:
Near the start of December @Studio Yorktown launched his "Studio Yorktown Color Town Hall" library of wonderful colour palettes.

"You know what this Town Hall needs?" I asked no one in particular, "Vents!". Besides, what's more Christmassy than a good old vent?

Some nice soothing gradients, with a selection of innies and outies, structure, form, and sometimes sharp edges. I humbly suggest aiming to get a set of three 😁

Thank you for everything fxhash in 2022, looking forwards to 2023!

READ MORE: https://www.fxhash.xyz/article/vents

INSTRUCTIONS ::

h - Toggle high-res
n - toggle noise on/off
s - Download and save image

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS ::

High-res will output a 8,192 x 8,192 image, at 300dpi it should print at...

27.3 x 27.3 inches
69.3 x 69.3 cm

metadata.name: Nullteilung #54
metadata.description:
Nullteilung is another exercise in suprematism and composition. Born from a series of exercises in subdevision and tesselation, it seeks to connect with the user through the creation of a sense of order and balance in the composition.

The term "Nullteilung" a German word that can be translated to "zero division" which is suggesative of the order and disorder paramount in the piece, working toward a goal of emotional and programmatic purity.

Ancient generative patterns.

Press 's' or double click/tap to save a PNG
To save 2x, 4x, or 8x versions, press the '2', '3', '4' keys respectively.

Made with thi.ng.
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

metadata.name: Glossolalia #146
metadata.description:
This series is ultimately about catharsis. The compositions can be chaotic and maybe even a little messy, but they also can be vibrant and diverse… which is really what this is trying to celebrate: diversity and expression.

Simply, it’s about the emotions associated with whatever frees you.

Please see the linked fxtext article (on the main project page) for a more in-depth dissection of the concept. It’s less of a technical discussion, and more about the experience of the artist, and how it became linked with the feelings they associate with the art.

In live mode:

For higher resolutions, you can append “&density=2” to the url to double the size, “&density=3” to triple, and so on.
(This is highly recommended.)

To adjust grain, you can append “&grain=##” to the url. 40 is the default, and 0 will remove it completely.

metadata.name: Reaching #45
metadata.description:
Reach for the stars.

However impossible it may seem, there's always a way. As long as you believe.
Everybody has a way to their stars, and the only way to reach it is to try as hard as you can and believe in yourself. I will forever live by this and believe in it.

A couple of the palettes used in this piece were adapted from the ever great Studio Yorktown, thank you for providing these incredible combinations of colors :)

--

Press spacebar or right click to save an image.

--

Reaching is a piece I dedicate to my recently passed grandmother. Rest in piece, we love you and miss you.

metadata.name: Mecha-Bamboo #422
metadata.description:
Mecha-Bamboo is the second installment in the Mecha series, where I attempt to blend mechanical elements with nature.

The main building blocks used in this piece are metal pipes, nuts and bolts forming bamboo stems and mending plates extending outwards with sharp metal scraps at their ends resembling branches and leaves. 

There are 4 main arrangement variations 
	- Two abstract variations with the metal bamboos growing out of the sides and border (20% chance each)
	- Two landscape arrangements, one on flat planes and the other on floating platforms.  (30% chance each)

The dominant stroke and fill colors are chosen at random from the RGB color space and are only recomputed if certain contrast criteria aren't fulfilled. 
In combination with one of 10 hand-selected color palettes used for accents, this allows a great variation of different possible color schemes.

The structure and appearance of the bamboo, its stems and leaves are controlled by over 50 parameters that are chosen at random, giving each iteration a unique style.



Keys: 
S - Save PNG image
V - Open SVG Export menu
Space - Pause

Plotting:
You can export a plottable SVG of each iteration by opening the export menu. I plot these on A3 with a 0.1mm fineliner. But depending on the density of the iteration other choices might be better suited. 


The image is generated entirely in Javascript and the postprocessing is done with a custom shader. If there is no webgl support, the image will render without any postprocessing. You can force this by appending the URL parameter "?noWebgl=1".

Libraries used:
Three.js & EffectComposer
Javascript-Voronoi by gorhill
perlin.js by  Joseph Gentle
dat.gui

metadata.name: Der Ast #195
metadata.description:
Der Ast is a work which grew from a love of triganometry. The tree grows and branches 
based on a fixed and finite set of rules and while this leads to some very self-similar 
structures, in some cases, it generally allows for some very detailed complexity and 
surprise overall.

In this system, a box is drawn and on top of it, a right-angled triangle. The triangle
has an α angle conforming to a set formula (for example, in one system the angle follows)
a sinewave along the bough). From this triangle we construct the next square/triangle
set upon the hypotenuse and, if the β is wide enough, a second branch sprouts from the 
adjacent side.

This work is intended to be printed, and so included are controls to allow you to download
a high-resolution version as well as to create any aspect you wish.

- Append &dpr=x to the URL where DPR is the pixel density you want. This defaults to 2
- Append &fs=true to the URL to scale the token to the size of your browser
- Append &width=x and &height=y to the URL to scale the token to a specific size

Double-click/tap to download.

metadata.name: Iteration is Usually Recursive (Pt. 1) #4
metadata.description:
This is the companion piece released with 'Iteration is Usually Recursive — Introduction: Finding answers in pre-computational art', the first in a series of essays, some long, some short, on generative art, theory and the practitioners of the medium. 

This piece started a simple experimen recreating George Nees’ Schotter (1968)— a classic piece of generative art history — as vanilla js SVG graphics. From there, I specifically developed it with non-plotter printing in mind, and more specific still, Riso Printing (think a scanner with a digital screen-printer MacGyver’d on). The palettes are taken from hex-estimated Risograph colour gamuts, with three layers being multiplied together to replicate, to some degree, the blending of the semi-transparent Risographic inks. Within this study, there’s a few different things going on, the initial setup is rectangles which cascade down the canvas, inheriting more extreme rotation as they get closer to the bottom (a la Schotter). The second is a subdivision of the shapes with filled circled, outlined circles and squares — since in this study the base shapes are rectangles and not squares, distribution of the ‘dithering’ can be larger than a single ‘pixel’ size — when these multiple layers overlap, the shapes produce a halftone-moire effect, forms and structures appear from the noise as the underlying patterns intersect. 

tx: Who?, Cosimo, Liam Egan, Andreas Rau, Louis

Licensing: CC-BY-NC-ND

From there, I specifically developed it with non-plotter printing in mind, and more specific still, Riso Printing (think a scanner with a digital screen-printer MacGyver’d on). The palettes are taken from hex-estimated Risograph colour gamuts, with three layers being multiplied together to replicate, to some degree, the blending of the semi-transparent Risographic inks. Licensing: CC-BY-NC-ND
